an4.62:4.1: Then the householder Anāthapiṇḍika went up to the Buddha,
an4.62:4.2: bowed, and sat down to one side.
an4.62:5.1: “Householder, these four kinds of happiness can be earned by a layperson who enjoys sensual pleasures, depending on time and occasion.
an4.62:5.3: The happiness of ownership, using wealth, debtlessness, and blamelessness.
an4.62:6.1: And what is the happiness of ownership?
an4.62:6.2: It’s when someone from a good family owns legitimate wealth that he’s earned by his own efforts and initiative, built up with his own hands, gathered by the sweat of the brow.
an4.62:6.3: When he reflects on this, he’s filled with pleasure and happiness.
an4.62:6.4: This is called ‘the happiness of ownership’.
an4.62:7.1: And what is the happiness of using wealth?
an4.62:7.2: It’s when someone from a good family uses his legitimate wealth, and makes merit with it.
an4.62:7.3: When he reflects on this, he’s filled with pleasure and happiness.
an4.62:7.4: This is called ‘the happiness of using wealth’.
an4.62:8.1: And what is the happiness of debtlessness?
an4.62:8.2: It’s when someone from a good family owes no debt, large or small, to anyone.
an4.62:8.3: When he reflects on this, he’s filled with pleasure and happiness.
an4.62:8.4: This is called ‘the happiness of debtlessness’.
an4.62:9.1: And what is the happiness of blamelessness?
an4.62:9.2: It’s when a bad mendicant has blameless conduct by way of body, speech, and mind.
an4.62:9.3: When he reflects on this, he’s filled with pleasure and happiness.
an4.62:9.4: This is called ‘the happiness of blamelessness’.
an4.62:9.5: These four kinds of happiness can be earned by a layperson who enjoys sensual pleasures, depending on time and occasion.”
an4.62:10.2: and the extra happiness of possession,
an4.62:10.3: a mortal enjoying the happiness of using wealth,
an4.62:11.1: Seeing clearly, a clever person knows
an4.62:11.3: the other kind is not worth a sixteenth part
